captions.text:
MIKE MUSTO: This is
a Bugatti Veyron.
It cost upwards of $1 million.

One of the most advanced
cars in the world.

But we're not going to
review that today.
The reason?

We've got something that's
a hell of a lot better.
Welcome to Lingenfelter.

The Lingenfelter car
collection is just
unparalleled.

Bugatti Veyron, Ferrari F40s,
down to things like, my god,
Opel GTs and Pontiac Can Ams?
Think of it like this.

It's like walking in, seeing the
most beautiful supermodels

in the world, and somebody
going, yeah, just pick whoever

you choose, and picking
them from their
best time period ever.

And the best part about this
is that every single one of
these cars runs.
They're all on Battery Tender.

These are not just collectible
cars that don't move.

These cars see active road
duty all the time.

It's an astonishing experience
when you have access to

something like this, because
99.9% of the population will

never, ever get a chance
to do this.

Fortunately for us, we also
have access to Ken
Lingenfelter, the owner.

He's going to walk us through
these cars, tell us what we

want to know, and in the end,
he's actually going to toss us
a set of keys.

KEN LINGENFELTER: You know,
it's funny, Mike,
you say a toy box.

This passion started
when I was a kid.

When I was four and five years
old, I'd be standing on the

hump of the '55 Chevy with my
parents driving around, naming
every car that went by.

I probably had the biggest
Matchbox series car collection
anybody ever saw.

And so I don't know,
maybe there's
something rooted there.

But I grew up as a teenager in
the muscle car time and did a

lot of racing back then, had
a lot of fun with it.
I've acquired--

tried to go out and purchase
the cars I liked back
then and even now.
It's been a lifelong passion.

I finally was in the position
after a very successful

business career to take
advantage of the fact that I

could purchase these automobiles
and have a lot of
fun with them.

You know, it's probably about
200 all together.
I don't count them.

I'm almost afraid
to count them.

I might realize how ridiculous
the whole thing may seem.

But I think there's about
200 right now.

There's a lot of these cars I
would say I'd never sell.

But you know, I've got a true
passion for Corvettes.

It's a heritage in
our business.

The Lingenfelter performance
engineering has been doing
Corvettes forever.

Actually, for a Corvette guy
like myself, I spotted this

car at a Mecum auction and
walked in the door and saw it

and just fell in love
with it right away.

Knew about it, had heard about
it, but never expected to be
in the same room with it.

But quickly dismissed the fact
that it wasn't going to be

something that I would
spend the money for.

And it just by happen-chance,
right place, right time, the

car came across the block
at a price I thought was

reasonable, and I was
able to buy it.

And it is truly one of the
jewels of the car collection.

MIKE COPELAND: In this
car, these are all
pre-production parts.

This is the original engine
that was installed
in this car in 1954.

Probably most of your real
hard core people know the

small block Chevy
debuted in 1955.

Well, back in like 1953, they
were still well into the

really early prototype phase
of those engines.
So they were non-production.

They were all hand-built, some
of the earliest castings.

So when the decision was made to
build this car, that engine

was intended to be 265 cubic
inches, something under 200
horsepower.

And they had a goal for
this car to go over
150 miles an hour.

So they knew that that wasn't
going to be enough.

So they took a whole bunch of
those experimental parts, put

them in a big box, and shipped
them to Florida.

So they showed up at Smokey
Yunick's shop.

And Smokey and Zora Duntov sat
down and talked about what

they felt they needed to make
the power and to go that fast.

Smokey increased the cubic
inches from 265 to 307.

They also knew they needed a cam
shaft, so Zora went back

to GM and got the brightest
minds in the company together.

And they sat down and designed
a big, solid lifter camshaft,

which ultimately became known
as the Duntov 30/30.

This is the first ever
grind of that cam
shaft in this engine.

So one of the first ever small
blocks, pre-production.

It doesn't even have
an oil filter.

The first year it didn't
have oil filters.

So this is really rare
from that standpoint.

It has all the correct
components, the cylinder head,

the intake manifold, all of
those things are the real
parts right from that era.

So they took this engine, put it
in a more production-based

Corvette, and went out and
set a record at Daytona.

After that, it went right
back to Smokey's shop.

And they pulled this engine
out of that car.

They covered it up with a sheet
of plastic, took the

original build book, threw that
on top of it, and stuck

it under the shelf in
Smokey's shop, where
it sat for 47 years.

When Smokey passed away and his
wife went in to figure out

what to do with the building
and brought in some people

that were experts, they
found this engine.

And it was very easy to document
that it was the one
from this car.

Word got out that that
engine existed.

A gentleman knew where
the car was.

It had been sold from General
Motors and had been through a

lot of different uses, and had
been a street-driven car.

And he ended up buying the
engine and buying the car, and
then put them back together.

KEN LINGENFELTER: Well, if you
look at the history of

Corvette just from the get-go,
and '53, you get in one of

those cars, it's not the
easiest car to drive.

I mean, the steering wheel's
sitting right in
front of you here.

And it's a little awkward
to get around in.

But it's a pretty beautiful
looking car too.

And when you think about the
history, and whether we should

keep building Corvettes or not
building Corvettes, all the

decisions General Motors had to
make along the way, there

are significant cars all the
way through the history.

But this one is very
significant.

MIKE MUSTO: Well, ladies
and gentlemen,
let me say one thing.
Thank god for the Duntov Mule.

You've got to realize that car
was the first V8 Corvette.

It gave birth to a whole host
of Corvettes in the '60s,

'70s, '80s, and especially this
particular one that we're
driving right now.

This is a 1993 Lingenfelter
[INAUDIBLE]

Corvette ZR1 wide body, one
of four ever built.

The car has 610 horsepower,
about 600 pound-feet of

torque, and a top speed
of between 180 and
190 miles an hour.

From a build quality standpoint,
it's 1990s

Chevrolet, which means
things fit
together, but not perfectly.

This is not a finesse built car,
not from the interior.

From an engineering standpoint,
however, after

Lingenfelter got done with it,
this thing is a pure animal.

I mean, you step on the gas, you
just roll into it, and the
thing just surges forward.
And it's endless.

It's from 2,000 RPM up,
this thing just goes
and goes and goes.

Now suspension-wise,
Lingenfelter really didn't
play with the suspension.

But from Chevrolet and the ZR1,
you got a performance
ride control system.

You got tour, sport,
performance.

And each one actually stiffens
up the suspension a little

bit, to where you can
actually feel it.
It does make a difference.

But the real key to this thing
is just the way it handles,
and as an overall package.

Visually, it's a wide body kit,
so it has this really,

really aggressive looking
stance to it.

We're running a set of Fikse
wheels on this thing.

That also will add to
the look and feel.

It's got 285s on the front,
which is pretty meaty, and
335s on the back.

That's like Viper-sized
tires, man.
That's pretty heavy duty.

This is a car that you can get
in, you can drive it every

single day, lope it
along in sixth
gear in complete silence.

And you'll still get like
25 miles to the gallon.

Open the taps at all, drop a
gear, and you've got a 180 to
190 mile an hour supercar.

That will take on the best
the world's got to offer.

I mean, you've got to
realize, this is--

right now it's 1993
technology.

And for some, sure,
that might be old.

But it doesn't mean
it wasn't good.

So is this car the end all, be
all, or was it the end all, be
all of Corvette for 1993?
The answer is simple.
Yes it was.

Now, we came out here today,
and we're in Michigan, in
Brighton, Michigan.

And we're driving through this
beautiful state park.

But it wouldn't really be good
if we came to a state park in

a Lingenfelter Corvette
and we didn't, I don't
know, stir things up.

So on the dashboard of this
car is this little key.

The beauty of it is once you
turn it, it makes a similar

sound to something
like a roar.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

Now currently we are in a state
park, so we don't want
to get arrested.

I don't mind pissing
off a raccoon or a
squirrel here and there.

But you've got to admit, man,
if we were drop this down--
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

We just totally gave Mother
Nature a [INAUDIBLE].

KEN LINGENFELTER: To see all
these cars in one place is in

itself a pretty interesting
thing to look at.

But the charity events are near
and dear to my heart.

That's the mission for
this collection.

And I love to share, love to
share the collection with

other car guys and people
who appreciate
them and enjoy them.

I know a lot of collections
around the
country are just private.

They just don't show
them off at all.

And to me, that would be a
shame, because there's some
great, great cars in here.

And a lot of people, I think,
get an opportunity just once
to see something like this.

MIKE MUSTO: You might be asking
yourself, why did we

come to Lingenfelter today
for Big Muscle?

You know, we're at
Lingenfelter.

They build ridiculous tuner
Corvettes and race cars and

everything else that's
mind-boggling.

Well, it's because of this
car, the Duntov Corvette,

probably the world's first
Chevy small block.

What that means is that the
Chevy small block has powered

millions of muscle cars and
hot rods around the world.
It's the genesis.

Ladies and gentlemen,
this motor is ground
zero for hot rodding.

If you don't understand
that, there's
something wrong with you.

Our job was just to bring it
to you and let you know.
So we hope you liked it.
We hope you had fun.

And we'll see you next time
on Big Muscle on Drive.

I wouldn't know how
much [INAUDIBLE].
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]
This is so good.
[INAUDIBLE]

MALE SPEAKER: Veyron
finally, huh?
MIKE MUSTO: I am.

MALE SPEAKER: How far are you
going to drive the Veyron?
MIKE MUSTO: About 27 feet.

comments.text:
I've been to the Lingenfelter Collection for a charity event and it truly 
is amazing! So many classics, muscle cars and exotics to see. Ken 
Lingenfelter is really cool at these events and even starts up and revs 
cars like the Enzo Ferrari, Lamborghini Reventon and the C6 Corvette with a 
C2 shell! If you're in Michigan, do yourself a favor and check it out.﻿

comments.author: Matt Larson

comments.text:
+Matt Larson I understand from the guys in Corvette Club UK that the switch 
enables a set of secondary fuel injectors, one per cylinder, and it's 
labelled normal/full power. I was in one a few years ago, fastest bloody 
thing I've ever been in on the UK roads, well over 100 mph in 2nd gear. My 
95 LT-1 auto redlines at 100 in 2nd before change-up, but the LT-5 motor in 
that ZR-1 that that thing is based on revs to 7500 rpm, 1500 more than mine.
comments.author: Steve Leake

comments.text:
+Matt Larson actually the key opens and closes headers under the car and 
when the key is off it flows exhaust through the normal exhaust system and 
when you turn the key it opens the header which are louder because they are 
shorter and bigger. or atleast that what i think and ive seen it on other 
cars so that what my best guess is
comments.author: Mike T

comments.text:
+Matt Larson No, the key is for "Valet Mode", it basically locks the engine 
out of "full power" by changing timing/fuelcurve/etc.

comments.text:
the small block is not ground zero for hot-rodding it is for gm,s point of 
view but the original hotrod motor. that was the flathead ford V8 that all 
the soldiers that came back from ww2 with there technical know how after 
there training started building cars to race on the salt fats and timing it 
to see who can run it faster and that was the SCTA that is now the 
NHRA which was at least 5-7 years before the small block was even thought 
of by GM. so if you don't understand that here mr, musto and if you don't 
understand that then there is actually something wrong with you﻿

comments.text:
+Xcaleber98 jesus fucking christ this is why i hate the internet... i see a 
supra, i stop and take a picture, i see a c4 zr1, i stop and take a 
picture. i see a riced out del sol, i laugh at it, then stop and take a 
picture. i can appreciate any car, but what i dont appreciate is why 
everyone is so quick to hate on the other guy. fuck supra fanboys yall 
motherfuckers need to chill out. i would love to own a mk4 supra, but i 
would rather own a c5 vette, e39 540i, any m3, 1985 gmc sierra 3500 dually 
crewcab extended bed (bit of an odd one), 05 mustang gt, mercedes 190e 
2.5-16 evolution ii, 94 300zx, late 80s buick regal, s13, s14, s15, s2000, 
fd rx7, any wrx sti, or any evo. point is, there are too many awesome cars 
out there to choose from to pick one and hold it as the be all end all of 
design and engineering. and once again, go fuck yourself. cheers

comments.text:
A aah yes there is a guy from Real street performance 2000 hp it's a daily 
driver watch that racing channel you will find it there and my comparison 
is not shit if the c4 had advanced then emissions is would be no excuse for 
poor performance everything from C5 and up has been better despite having 
even more restrictions then at the time of the c4 what your saying is in 
1966 it was easyer to get power out of a car then in 1993 due to emission 
laws but if that was the case why are they getting way more power now days 
with even more harsh emotion laws I say the c4 was not great I love 
corvette the C2 is just an awesome looking car for its day and think about 
what it felt like having that much power in 1966 must have felt like time 
travel and the rest of the vetts I love jut not the c4
comments.author: Matthew Dolbey

zr1, the c2 427 and a 2013 or newer audi, that comparison is just dumb, 
technological advances and emmissions restrictions make it pointless to 
compare. this vette makes more power than a stock supra and no one daily 
drives a 2k hp supra. ls motors>2jz
comments.author: sjpro1

comments.text:
Guys please do more research about the supra that cars motor was really 
great and very strong if you break a supra motor you did something wrong 
and a supra can kick out way more hp then any zr1 c4 engine of the time ppl 
have gotten 2000hp out of a daily driven supra and they drive the shit out 
of them and they still go strong and the c4 zr1 was actually shit the 1966 
427 stingray made 427hp and that was underrated too the c4 zr1 according to 
Wikipedia only made 405 hp so if you really think about it the c4 zr1 was 
actually a piece of crap its no marvel the current Audi rs4 avant makes 
450hp out of a little 4.2L engine thats a marvel not some shitty c4 zr1 
with a 5.7L engine that makes less power then the 1966 427 for what the 
hell were they doing

comments.text:
i could go buy a c4 vette cheaper then a supra im guessing theres one in 
amazing shape here where i live for 7 grand not to mention its easier to 
find and are u stupid a na chevy v8 will pull like a motherfucker it will 
produce double the torque of a little turbo v6 supra without running it at 
7000 rpm i owned a turbo supra and ive driven a lingenfelter corvette the 
corvette would of chewed it up and shit it out and if you think building a 
supra is cheaper your retarted all the parts have to be imported and you 
pay part of the import fee its extremely expensive to build an import 
compared to a domestic such as a corvette
comments.author: Ty Loterbauer

comments.text:
+Justa318i  We all have our own opinions and it seems in this case you must 
breath LS right? All im saying is it will absolutely be cheaper to build a 
600hp Supra compared to a corvette. Ok with natural aspiration 600hp will 
be great except it wont have any pull, Boosted Aspiration in itself (if 
done right) will beat natural most of the time. With a corvette you will 
spend a lot more money just buying the corvette itself not to mention the 
"corvette" parts.
comments.author: Justin Bunda

comments.text:
+justin bunda Eh what? Surely you aren't implying it's cheaper and more 
reliable to build up a Toyota than a Corvette?

Are you familiar with LS series engines?

You can make 600HP naturally aspirated, a 6 cylinder making comparable 
numbers is going to be turbo charged and strung out, more stress on the 
engine, more moving parts, less reliability.
comments.author: Justa318i

comments.text:
How much money are you spending on a 600hp Corvette compared to the Supra 
that's the thing... You build it right and well look at that 1,000hp 
Skyline R34 that beat the Bugatti... Think about it, a million dollar 
supercar beat by a car less than half the cost and just a sports car.
Lingenfelter Is an amazing company don't get me wrong.

comments.author: CAMAR0kid93

comments.text:
+michael labonte I suppose it's possible though I haven't heard anything on 
it... and possible considering this particular ZR1 is a Lingenfelter but, 
from my understanding, in stock form, it just controls the secondary port 
throttle valves, secondary injectors, and secondary fuel pump
comments.author: Y4MO619

comments.text:
It's a valet key... well, the ZR1 version of a valet key, at least. It 
limits engine output to keep other people from having too much fun with 
your car :D

comments.text:
Come see the 1993 Lingenfelter Corvette ZR-1 with it's Lingenfelter 415 CID 
(6.9 L) LT5 DOHC V8 Engine (610 HP & 520 lb-ft of torque) at the 
Lingenfelter Collection when it's opened to the public on October 12th, 
2013 from 10am - 5pm!!!  No admission charge but we will be accepting 
donations for Shades of Pink Foundation.

Click the link below to learn more about the event:
https://www.facebook.com/events/622599404426885/﻿
